member.name: T:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Activex.MakeNewInstanceDelegate
member.summary: Classes migrated from an ActiveX-Dll or ActiveX-Exe have internal contructors. This is done to make sure that this classes are not instantiated directly. Due to this restriction a method is added to the Factory to instantiate classes and that method is "passed" to the ComponentServerImplementations with a delegate of this type.
member.param: The type of the instance you want

member.name: T:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Activex.ProcessManager
member.summary: When the user request to create a class that is inside an ActiveX project, it is necesary to perform several steps: 1. Determine in which EXE is the class located 2. Determine if the .EXE is already running 3. Start a new process if it is necessary. This class encapsultes all this logic

member.name: M:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Activex.ProcessManager.LoadAllComponentInfo
member.summary: Loads all .EXE in found in the search path and setups some metadata needed to determine the .EXE file that must be started as a new server The search path can be specified in the App.Config file. just add an entry like:

member.name: M:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Activex.ProcessManager.CurrentDomain_ReflectionOnlyAssemblyResolve(System.Object,System.ResolveEventArgs)
member.summary: We must make sure that the Manager is able to load all required dependencies. As an optimization, only reflection information is loaded. While the reflection information is loaded it might happen that some assemblies are not loaded. This method provides some simple aid to find reflection information that was not available

member.name: M:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Activex.ProcessManager.GetFactory``1
member.summary: Obtains the factory to instanciate classes migrated from an ActiveX-Dll or an ActiveX-Exe. This method will locate the .exe file that contains those classes.
member.typeparam: A class is needed to determine which assembly contains it and start the new process
member.returns: A reference to the factory that can instanciate classes of T type

member.name: M:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Activex.ProcessManager.GetSemaphoreValue(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Semaphores are used to syncronize processes and have a deterministed way of getting a named pipe name. This is mostly due to limitatios on the Remoting.
member.param: Indicates that you want to get the semaphone name but you dont want to modify it

member.name: M:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Activex.ProcessManager.StartProcess(System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.String[])
member.summary: Starts the process and makes sure that it is syncronizeds
member.param: Path for the .EXE file that will be started
The process name is used for syncronization
When a process is created a semaphore is used for syncronization issues between server and client. The semValue is then used to create a syncEvent
Arguments to be passed to start the process
member.returns: The Process that has just been started

member.name: M:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Activex.ComponentServerHelperBase`1.InitializeGlobalVarsIfNeeded
member.summary: One of the possible implementations for ActiveX-Dll and ActiveX-Exe can be to migrate the classes as close as posible to standard .NET classes. However the instancing behaviour of VB6 requires that when all instances of classes of an activex-exe are removed that global vars have to be reset to their original values. To reproduce that behaviour, a list of delegates can be kept to reset those variables. The default implementation does nothing of this.

member.name: T:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Gui.ContainerHelper
member.summary: It is very common in VB6 to implement algorithms that tranverse the Controls collection for a Form or UserControl. During migration some issues appear in the target platform because the controls collection in .NET is not flat but hierarquical. This issue will break a lot of the original logic, that assumes that all controls present in the Form or UserControl will be present in one big collection. This Helper Class provides several methods that allows to traverse the .NET components collections in an easy and direct way, just as it was possible in VB6.

member.summary: Returns the NestedControlEnumerator for the control

member.summary: Gets the delegates bound to an event in an object.
member.returns: Null if no delegates or event were found.

member.summary: Method to add a list of events to the cache.
member.param: The object target to use as key.

member.summary: Event handler release resources when a component is disposed.

member.summary: This method is obsolete, use ControlArrayHelper instead.

member.summary: This method is obsolete, use ControlArrayHelper instead.

member.name: T:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Gui.ContainerHelper.ControlArray
member.summary:
.NET does not implement the VB6 concept of controls arrays. During migration these arrays are generated as Arrays of Controls, but these arrays are not Controls. So they are not present in the Controls collections of a Form or UserControl. So to perform things like:
Form1.Controls("MyTextBoxControlArray")
A class that will be able to "wrap" the array of controls and make it "behave" like a Control. and gives access to those elements.

member.name: F:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Gui.ContainerHelper.ControlArray.controlArray
member.summary: A reference to the actual array.

member.name: M:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Gui.ContainerHelper.ControlArray.#ctor(System.Windows.Forms.Control[])
member.summary: Builds a ControlArray object that will "wrap" the specified array, to make it be "seen" as a Control.
member.param: The control array that will be wrapped.

member.name: M:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Gui.ContainerHelper.ControlArray.#ctor(System.Array)
member.summary: Builds a ControlArray object that will "wrap" the specified array, to make it be "seen" as a Control. This overload is used when the Control Array has a different type. Supported array types are: * Control * ToolStripItem * MenuStrip
member.exception: Thrown when an array with unsupported type is used.
member.param: The control array that will be wrapped.

member.name: P:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Gui.ContainerHelper.ControlArray.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the Control at the specified index position.

member.name: P:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Gui.ContainerHelper.ControlArray.Item(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the Control at the specified index position.

member.name: P:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Gui.ContainerHelper.ControlArray.Length
member.summary: Returns the Length of the subyacent array.

member.name: T:UpgradeHelpers.VB6.Gui.ImageListHelper
member.summary: Control created to convert the images of a VB6 ImageList into an internal .NET ImageList. This control can be used in design time or runtime - Design Time: Add the control to the form with the VB6 ImageList, use the property VB6ImageList to indicate the name of the VB6 ImageList and use the property NETImageList to access the .NET ImageList with the images migrated - Runtime: Creates an instance of this control and use the method LoadVB6ImageList with a VB6 ImageList as parameter to migrate it in runtime, again, use the property NETImageList to access the .NET ImageList with the images migrated note: Some images may not be converted into the .NET ImageList so in such cases a default error image is used, the workaround is to change the original image in the VB6 ImageList to another format.
